entry.title: spatial snipe
entry.msg:
Only the second number needs to be applied with 2's complement.

(a - b) = a + (2's complement of b) 

More examples: 
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/subtraction-of-two-numbers-using-2s-complement/ (Links to an external site.)
https://courses.cs.vt.edu/csonline/NumberSystems/Lessons/SubtractionWithTwosComplement/index.html (Links to an external site.)

entry.title: skilled silkworm
entry.msg:
Hi Summer, 

for part 1D, you have to inverse just the number you are subtracting by. 

For example:  A - B = A + ( - B )

entry.title: relieved quail
entry.msg: If the sum of 2 positive numbers returns a negative number then the sum has overflowed. If the sum of 2negative numbers returns a positive result, then the sum has overflowed. A good way to check for overflow is by looking at the MSB (most significant bit), where 0 represents positive and 1 represents negative. I hope this helps.

I am still not very clear yet on how to check OV. 

From this source: http://faculty.cs.niu.edu/~byrnes/csci360/notes/360numsys.htm (Links to an external site.)

Copy from the above link:

Overflow:

Occurs when a number becomes too large for its representation scheme.

To check for overflow:

  1. Convert the 1st digit of each number to binary
  2. Add the binary values together
  3. If the last two carry bits are the same, no overflow.
  4. If they are different, overflow.

entry.title: supposed swordtail
entry.msg:
Hello Akash,

When converting binary to hexadecimal, you use the same process regardless of how the binary representation is read. Hexadecimal notation can be interpreted as a shorthand for binary with each letter representing 4 bits. For example, 1001 = -7 is 0x9 in hexadecimal.

entry.msg: what is overflow and how do we find it?

entry.title: advanced anaconda
entry.msg:
Hi Darren,

Basically overflow occurs in two conditions:

  1. Two negative numbers are added but the result becomes positive.
  2. Two positive numbers are added but the result becomes negative.

Here is a link of page that shows how we can detect overflow by using a 2-bit comparator:

https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/overflow-in-arithmetic-addition-in-binary-number-system/

entry.title: conscious cattle
entry.msg:
Hi Darren,

Overflow indicates that we have done a calculation that resulted in a number larger than the largest number we can represent. 
For instance, when two unsigned numbers are added, overflow occurs if 
- there is a carry out of the leftmost bit.
The explanation given by Jingyun above works for when two signed 2â€™s complement numbers are added.

entry.title: shiny shark
entry.msg:
Hello Su Hyeon!

I confirmed with the professor during his office hour - yes we need to show our work step by step so he knows we just didn't google and give the answer :)

 

This is what I did for one of the questions:

 (5 points) Assume unsigned addition: 
    348263 
   +73C698
   Steps: 
   3 + 8 = 11 = B
   6 + 9 = 15 = F
   2 + 6 = 8
   8 + C = 8 + 12 = 16 + 4 (carry 1 to digit to the left)
   4 + 3 + 1 (carryover) = 8
   3 + 7 = A

   Answer: A848FB

 

Hope this helps!
